info.title: When not to use rootless containers

topic.para: Although &podman; makes it easy to run containers in rootless mode, there are scenarios, where that is not an option.

listitem.para: &&slem; does not allow regular users, thus making it impossible to run containers in rootless mode.

You need the container to have write access to the host's file system. For example, you need to launch a container using a database dump stored in /var/lib/postgresql and being able to write data to it.
You need to bind the container to port lower than 1024, without reconfiguring sysctl.

topic.para: Running containers in rootless mode have several drawbacks that you need to be aware of.

para.para: Because unprivileged users cannot configure network namespaces on Linux, &podman; relies on a user space network implementation called slirp4netns. It emulates the full TCP-IP stack and can cause a heavy performance degradation for workloads relying on high network transfer rates. This means that rootless containers suffer from slow network transfers.

listitem.para: On Linux, unprivileged users cannot open ports below port number 1024. This limitation also applies to &podman;, so by default, rootless containers cannot expose ports below port number 1024. You can remove this limitation using the following command: sysctl net.ipv4.ip_unprivileged_port_start=0.
To remove the limitation permanently, run sysctl -w net.ipv4.ip_unprivileged_port_start=0.
Note that this allows all unprivileged applications to bind to ports below 1024.
